experience.description: As the Principal Engineer of Accelerated Engineering, my role involves building and leading teams committed to advancing early-stage platform capabilities. Our focus is on enhancing the adoption of spatial computing in various enterprise contexts. Our engineers navigate the space between emerging technologies, including the most recent AI/ML innovations, and practical, applicable solutions. This approach underscores our dedication to innovation, quality, and delivering exceptional value to our clients.

Collaborating with and learning from machine learning, data science, robotics, and IoT specialists, eventually being able to build with those specialities independently. recommendations.recommendation:
“I really enjoyed working with Joe because he is a great engineer and teammate. He is highly productive, dependable, and easy to work with.

As a senior member of the Android team, Joe led a range of initiatives — from the development of valuable new features (e.g., DoubleTake improvements) to stuff that just had to get done (e.g., tracking analytics events). I could always count on Joe to deliver with a high-degree of self-initiative and tenacity. His output was high-quality, timely, and transparently communicated.

Joe tends to ask the right questions, whether it is to deeply understand the problem to solve, clarify goals, or define constraints. I recall having felt in several planning sessions that I needed to be better prepared with sharper thinking or stronger proof. He regularly challenged me to bring my best. And, I believe he has that effect on everyone around him.

On a personal note, it was fun hanging out with Joe during late nights at the office. He is easy to talk to and has many interests, including technology, Stephen King novels, and movies. I find Joe to be supportive and generous (e.g., he introduced me to a fellow product manager) and would love to work with him again.

I strongly recommend him.”

projects.name: SimpleFragments
projects.description: SimpleFragments is a library aimed at making flexible Fragment navigation easy on Android while removing unneccessary lifecycle complications. The library makes it easy to create map-based navigation, stack-based navigation, or a combination of both. Back presses and rotation are handled.

projects.name: Ugly Weather
projects.description: A basic weather app with hand-drawn graphics. This app is published on the play store and the code is on my github: https://github.com/JayyyR/UglyWeather. I developed it in a reactive way using Kotlin and MVVM with Android's Lifecycle Components. It also uses my own navigation library, SimpleFragments, as well as RxJava2, Android Databinding, and other modern libraries.

projects.name: PlexPyMonitor
projects.description: Android app I started building for monitoring stats for your Plex Server using the PlexPy API: https://github.com/JonnyWong16/plexpy The app uses my PancakesOnPlates Library and the Android Data Binding framework. App is still a work in progress. I've just been working on it for fun.

projects.name: PancakesOnPlates
projects.description: PancakesOnPlates is a View-based navigation library for Android. It is forked from Github user mattlogan's Pancakes library. PancakesOnPlates aims to expand upon Pancakes and make it more versatile. It allows for any class to contain an ordered stack of Views or an order-less map of Views. It also provides a convenience class called Screen that extends a FrameLayout and can be thought of as a much simpler replacement for a Fragment. The library is supposed to provide an alternative to using multiple Fragments and Activities in Android. You can use PancakesOnPlates to create apps with rich navigation all while containing only one Activity and zero Fragments. The library is currently in a beta release. Show less

projects.name: Rover Android
projects.description: Rover is Epic's acute care mobile application integrated with EpicCare Inpatient allowing nurses and respiratory therapists to perform their common tasks on the go instead of being tied to a workstation. These functions include bar code medication administration, basic flow sheet documentation, specimen collection, reviewing patient info and completing work list tasks. The Android version provides organizations with an alternative to iOS which allows for a larger selection of devices and integrated barcode scanning. Search for Epic Rover in the play store to find out more! Show less

projects.name: Buff Buddy
projects.description: This is a workout tracker app I have been developing in my spare time. It is published on the Google Play store. The app lets you enter your own exercises and track your workouts. It tells you important information during your workout like what exercise you should be doing, what set you're on, and how much time has passed since your last set. The app also has Android Wear support so you can track your workout right from your wrist.

experience.description: I joined the Advanced Architectures & Research group at Cisco straight out of graduate school. A highly atypical group within the company, its mission was to drive forward-looking cross-functional programs, architectures, and research to help Cisco build a more unified product portfolio. I was fortunate enough to work alongside some prominent senior engineers (including a Cisco Fellow and a couple Distinguished Engineers), who were great mentors for the beginning of my career. A couple of the most interesting projects I worked on were in the areas of Cloud Storage and in Vehicular Networks. For the former, I build a proof-of-concept cloud gateway that provided policy-driven data tiering onto the cloud. This leveraged Cisco's Filesystem Virtualization technology (formerly NeoPath Networks). I worked together with the co-founder and CTO of NeoPath to integrate this functionality into the product. The latter involved defining the hardware and software architecture of a Smart Connected Vehicle platform, where we worked closely with many of the R&D labs of leading car manufacturers. My focus was on platform security technologies, such as Trusted Computing, Intel TXT, and Secure Boot. Other projects that I worked on involved setting up a public cloud infrastructure utilizing Cisco’s UCS and Nexus product lines and Linux KVM virtualization, initiating a Smart Grid architecture research effort focused on defining the architecture of Neighborhood Area Networks, and developing a distributed network measurement framework. Show less

headline: Director of Engineering, Academic Technology at Risepoint
summary: Director of Engineering, Academic Technology at Risepoint. Currently managing and collaborating with multiple teams of engineers across six different products/services. I work with product owners, scrum masters, business analysts, full time engineers and individual contributors, qa engineers and testing specialists, designers, and business stakeholders to steward projects from business asks, through design and scoping, into development, and ultimately, deployment to production. I team up with DevSecOps to manage our build pipelines, with QA engineers to implement Automated Testing solutions (Cypress/Playwright/Selenium), and I configure monitoring tools (New Relic, Sentry, Pingdom, PagerDuty) to track our database performance, health of our kubernetes (AKS/EKS) clusters, and maintain uptime and availability across our applications. I manage our release schedule and development workflow on feature branches, perform code reviews, trigger our builds in collaboration with DevSecOps who execute deployment, and maintain our teams' commitment to SOC 2 compliance. I audit and contribute to our Security training and org-wide best practices, as well as maintain our existing codebase and external dependencies - addressing vulnerabilities as they arise. I continue to contribute code across the tech stack writing mostly in Haxe and C#, working with Node.js and PostgreSQL. Over the years, I have hosted (and migrated) applications on Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, and Amazon Web Services. As an Open Source contributor, I often work in TypeScript in React, Express, and Node.js. Previous teaching fellow and instructor of Data Structures and Algorithms @Codesmith. Public talks (2021): "AR, The Future, and Why It's Already Here", SingleSprout Speaker Series. Find me on GitHub @ j-maltese.

publications.title: Robotics: A Project Based Approach
publications.description: Have you ever thought of building your own robot? With today’s technology, it’s easy (and inexpensive!) to get started in this fascinating hobby. With the projects in this book and just a little bit of programming knowledge, you can create fun, functional robots. You’ll learn the fundamentals of robot-building—the basic concepts and technologies that are used every day in the growing field of robotics. Each of the book’s projects is presented in clear step-by-step fashion, so you can follow along at your own pace. Projects include a traveling robot, an intruder alarm detector, a medical assistant, a data logger, and more. The technology used in this book is based on the Arduino platform, a popular open-source tool based on easy-to-use hardware and software. Get started building your own robots today, with ROBOTICS: A PROJECT-BASED APPROACH. Show less

publications.title: A Robotic Interactive Learning Environment To Teach Physics
publications.description: RILE is a Robotic Interactive Learning Environment to teach Physics at the middle and high school level. It consists of a set of custom made robots, which can be controlled by the teacher or student, via WI-FI, using a GUI. Each concept in Physics is expressed through multiple robotic activities. The environment includes a complete curriculum, consisting of instruction screens, background material for the teacher, experimental procedures, and an online student logbook, which the teacher can grade. The activities include exercises promoting multiple representations of conceptual knowledge - verbal, pictorial, graphical, and algebraic. Show less

publications.title: Tele-Robotics For Online Networking And Telecommunications Courses
publications.description: Online students often miss the experience of hands-on laboratory activities which are crucial for science courses. To address this issue we have developed an infrastructure which uses tele-robotics to provide laboratory experiences to students enrolled in networking and tele-communication courses. The unique aspect of this experiment is that these are not virtual labs, but these are labs in which physical robots are situated and students can manipulate these robots through a web interface using various principles of networking. Students responses to this experiment have been very positive and revealed that they have achieved the learning outcomes for each of these labs in a very decisive manner. Show less

publications.title: The Design And Implementation Of  Tele-Robotics in Education
publications.description: The TRE Systems provides a much needed solution to the increasing problem involving students interested in technical subjects, such as Computer Science and Physics. We address this issue at the source, the student's early academic experiences in middle and high school, where exposure to technical subjects is limited due to their cost and the nature of secondary institutions. TRE provides a transparent system through which students can interact with robots located in the classroom or in a remote lab. Most importantly, TRE Provides an abstracted environment, allowing the creation of different modules for different functionality based on student experience and the content being taught or exposed. This makes the system versatile enough for primary school students to solve a maze, or high school students to discover the physical representation of a derivative. We describe the architecture, the goals and an initial experiment of the TRE platform. Show less

publications.title: Android App Inventor for the Absolute Beginner
publications.description: Even if you've never tried programming before, Android App Inventor lets you quickly and easily create apps that will run on the Android platform. Whether you're a first-timer or a seasoned application developer, ANDROID APP INVENTOR FOR THE ABSOLUTE BEGINNER has something for you. Beginners will find clear step-by-step instructions and a thorough introduction to this fun and intuitive visual programming environment. Experienced developers will enjoy the coverage of more advanced topics, including various sensors, robotics, and TinyWebDB. Mobile app development is booming; there's never been a better time to get started. With Android App Inventor (free, open source software created by Google and MIT) and this book, you can design an app and upload it to your device in as little as 30 minutes. No prior experience in programming is necessary--and you don't need to be a math or graphics wiz. Get ready for a fun and fascinating introduction to app development with ANDROID APP INVENTOR FOR THE ABSOLUTE BEGINNER. Show less

publications.title: RILE: Robotic Interactive Learning Environment
publications.description: We report the design and alpha-testing of a Remote Interactive Learning Environment (RILE) to teach introductory one-dimensional kinematics to middle school students. The en- vironment is centered around robots which are controlled via WI-FI, and are equipped with sonar sensors to provide distance vs. time data. A student can remote-login via an application and perform experiments on kinematics on the robots and un- derstand the usually difficult concepts of displacement, velocity, and acceleration. The system was initially tested in a middle school for multiple batches of students at the 8th grade level. Initial reactions show that the students were engaged, interested, and excited. In particular, the excitement of working with real robots kept the students alert to pitfalls in the understanding of kinematics, as shown by their responses to qualitative questions on interpretation of graphical data. Show less

projects.name: ITEP: Project Robo-Explore
projects.description: Project Robo-Explore is a test case of using robotics labs to enhance online distance learning courses, such as Networking Fundamentals. This project focused on creating modules for the RILE Platform which could be used to teach basic networking skills in a fundamentally immersive way. By creating a specific laboratory exercise for each chapter, students were given access to database, networking, external devices and robots with real world connections which must be manipulated to setup a specific work flow. In these labs, students learned and experimented with TCP/UDP concepts, databases, user authentication, routing and networking infrastructure in a real world, yet safe and constructive environment. Show less

summary: Engineering executive with a career spanning 18+ years and experience leading large, distributed organizations driving innovation, engineering excellence and transformative business growth. At the helm of Google Drive's product engineering team, Abhita's focus is enabling a billion consumers and enterprise users to store and access their content securely in the cloud, crafting AI and ML-powered features that enhance user experiences across multiple platforms. In this role, she manages a globally distributed org of 220 engineers across Boulder, New York, London and remote. In addition to leading technical strategy and execution, she excels at partnering closely with Product Management, UX, Sales, Marketing and multiple cross-org engineering teams in managing the overall business. Prior to Google Drive, Abhita spent 13 years leading Engineering teams in Google Ads. Her experience in Ads spanned everything from product engineering to core backend infrastructure serving ads on mobile apps, web, video and programmatic. Over the years, the products/systems Abhita and her teams have built are some of Google’s largest business-critical systems handling XXXM queries per second, 10s of billions of dollars in annual revenue and used by billions of users. Prior to Google, Abhita worked at Yahoo! where she had the opportunity to design and implement multiple components of Yahoo’s Display Advertising business from scratch. Abhita started her career at Oracle, where she worked on Oracle’s enterprise management suite of products. Abhita holds a Masters in Computer Science from Stanford University and a Bachelors in Computer Science and Engineering from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur. Strengths: ======== * Leading product engineering teams and/or platform engineering teams with a product component * Defining and leading large-scale multi-year projects requiring cross-functional, cross-geo collaboration * Evaluating customer needs, product goals and business objectives and translating them into meaningful engineering solutions that are feasible for teams to deliver * Driving “big picture” strategy while also having the capability to provide detailed technical guidance to the team, enabling them to execute and deliver more effectively * Building diverse, inclusive and high-performing teams with a collaborative, fun culture

recommendations.recommendation:
“Julian embodies what it means to be trusted here at Hinge Health-- he’s got so much responsibility and he takes ownership of everything he does, which makes it so easy to rely on him. He was responsible for much of the early growth of our engineering team after our series A and B rounds of funding and he’s helped build the foundation for the engineering team to grow. When we needed someone to take on the role of CISO, Julian stepped up again, and I am so impressed by the way he has helped build security systems here at Hinge Health.

He’s made it clear that while adhering to our security policies is everyone’s responsibility, those security policies and systems surrounding them need to be clear, thoughtful, and watertight-- he’s said he wants to make sure it “shouldn’t be possible” for people to made an accidental security issue-- in other words, the biggest onus of security is on him and his team, and he knows it’s key to build an operation where the possibility for human error is as low as possible.

And this sense of responsibility extends to his direct reports as well-- I’ve heard only wonderful things about his management style, and how supportive he is. He knows it’s his job to make sure his team has what they need to succeed, and as a result, he’s really earned their trust.”

He’s made it clear that while adhering to our security policies is everyone’s responsibility, those security policies and systems surrounding them need to be clear, thoughtful, and watertight-- he’s said he wants to make sure it “shouldn’t be possible” for people to made an accidental security issue-- in other words, the biggest onus of security is on him and his team, and he knows it’s key to build an operation where the possibility for human error is as low as possible.

And this sense of responsibility extends to his direct reports as well-- I’ve heard only wonderful things about his management style, and how supportive he is. He knows it’s his job to make sure his team has what they need to succeed, and as a result, he’s really earned their trust.”
